title: Panel session: The Promise and Perils of Found Data

author: Kevin Bowyer, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, University of Notre Dame

segmentation: One is scrubbed from the web or.
Download it from the web or whatever you want to call it.
And the other is logged in an operational scenario, and if you're more to the computer vision side and less to the biometric side, you're probably saying what in the world is an operational scenario.
And that's a great question because.

To me, the people who advocate this don't often define what they mean by operational scenario, but I think it means that there's an actual operational application in the real world from which we could extract some data after the fact.
I'll give another example, a specific example in a moment, and my controversial statement is that even though there are two different sources of found data.
They have different essential problems, but they both have essential problems relative to the laboratory or pant plan.
Data collections.
In other words, there are Achilles heel type weaknesses with both of these types of found data, and I think they're well demonstrated, or at least.
Well conjectured.
So for the scrub data.
If your image provenance is unknown other than I got it off the web, and here's the URL.
And there's no metadata.
Typically with these, nothing to say what camera took it.
Nothing to say where it was, nothing to say.
Who it was directly you're inferring from the image.
Quite often, the image matches the ground truth.
You can't really be certain what problem you solved.
That's the controversial part meant to provoke somebody to react, because saying you can't be certain what problem you solved, kind of.
And why do I say that well?
OK, you match some images and you said you match them and you recognize the person you got.
The identity correct?
Is that really true?
Convince me that it's true.
Maybe all the images of all the movie stars have all been photoshopped.
Quite likely they've all been photoshopped.
There are research papers written about detecting Photoshop versus non Photoshopped and maybe all the athletes.
In action, at least, none of those are photoshopped.
Well, this is correlation with the data, right?
How do you factor out that help in recognition to convince me that you've really solved the recognition problem?
I don't.
I don't know that you can.
I don't know how to propose that you would, and I think it should be on the people using the data and promoting the use of the data too.
The same thing could be for compression to convince us that.
There aren't some some hidden covariants to use your word that are undocumented that are sliding under the radar that are making this problem easier than it is in real life.
For the other one operational scenarios I'll I'll propose what I'm going to call an operational contradiction.
The better run the operational scenario is, the more successful, the better.
The higher quality.
The actual practicing real world application of the technology is.
The harder it is to use.
The data that produces for research purposes, and I think this is a general truth, and I'm going to give an example out of the iris recognition community.
And.
And Miss tan.
And so I'm not insulting this as an entire institution or anything like that.
Just this particular study.
So there's a study at NIST where they took an operational data set from Canadian border crossing.
Right, so as you frequent travelers across the border, you present your Irish.
You get a match score and this body of match scores runs hundreds of thousands of subjects and millions of match scores.
It's a huge data set, right?
When this first published the report, they said, well, it results from 1 two in matching.
Everyone should well the biometric biometrics people know what I'm talking Bout 1 Dan means I take this picture and I match it against every picture that I know.
The identity of the best match.
Assuming it's below a threshold is who I assume that person is.
Right?
Missed was wrong or the Iraq 6 authors were wrong.
In order to make the the application more friendly.
That is faster to get people through the queue at the border.
the Canadian Border Services people had done one to first matching.
So I take the iris image and I start searching it against the data set.
The moment I find the first one that's below threshold.
Because I didn't make you say who you were.
The moment I find the first one below threshold, I'm sort of committed to letting you cross the border.
The search through the rest of the data set to find the best match.
Is innocence aureille sense to the person wanting to get across the border quickly wasted time?
So their data set actually the results from one to first matching.
Which means that you've got a bunch of false matches in there that you've accepted.
You just don't know how many or which ones.
To a researcher, this is a disaster.
How do you prove to me that that data set is useful?
But I think this is an example of a general phenomena.
People worried about satisfying the customer in running a really good operational scenario do all sorts of little tricks and shortcuts.
That they don't explicitly document that.
Make it better for the customer, but worse for the researcher coming along afterwards using the data set.
So.

From a researcher's perspective, wanting to answer questions in a sound way, I think a planned data set is preferable to a found data set, whether it's scrubbed from the web or borrowed from an existing application.
That's all I'll say.
